answers: Bruges, Belgium (the second painter is Hans Memling)
parts: Name this work that includes the words “For he spoke, and it came to be; he commanded, and it stood firm" near God, who looks at a translucent, half-filled sphere. A possible self-portrait in this painting depicts a giant with a cracked, egglike torso being impaled by a tree.
This Dutch artist painted The Garden of Earthly Delights as well as multiple triptychs of The Last Judgment.

Bosch’s Last Judgment scene held in this city features a pink-clad Christ and is more hellish than his Vienna and Munich scenes. A painter who succeeded Petrus Christus as this city’s most prominent painter showed St. Michael wearing gold armor and holding scales in his The Last Judgment.

answers: Bandaranaike [accept Solomon Bandaranaike or Sirimavo Bandaranaike]
Sri Lankan Tamils [or Tamilians; Eelam Tamils; or Ceylon Tamils; accept the Tamil Tigers or the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam]
parts: Give this surname of Solomon, who was assassinated by a Buddhist monk after he signed a pact with the leader of the Federal Party. The first woman to become a prime minister in Asia had this last name.
Solomon Bandaranaike's pact with S.J.V. Chelvanayakam gave limited autonomy to people of this ethnic minority in Sri Lanka, who formed a paramilitary group known as their namesake "tigers."

This country brokered a 2002 ceasefire between the Tamil Tigers and the Sri Lankan government. Yitzhak Rabin agreed to recognize the PLO as the legitimate representative of the Palestinian people in a set of accords named after this country's capital.
Name this author of Conversations with Friends. In another novel, they wrote about the on-and-off relationship between the students Marianne and Connell.
The protagonists of Conversations with Friends attend open mic nights around this city. The frame story of At Swim-Two-Birds is about a student in this capital city.

In Rooney's Normal People, Connell is agitated by reading a passage from this Jane Austen novel where it seems like Harriet Smith might marry George Knightley. This book's title character is an aspiring matchmaker.
Name this kind of event that occurs at the end of a certain opera's first act. Ned Keene calms a pub crowd by singing a round after a town outcast arrives during this kind of event.

Ellen Orford brings an apprentice to the title character of this opera while a storm strikes the Borough. This opera ends with that title fisherman drowning himself on the advice of Captain Balstrode.
Peter Grimes is an opera by this British composer of a War Requiem and The Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra. This composer's partner Peter Pears (peerz) played lead roles in many of his operas.

answers: fetal bovine serum [accept FBS, blood serum, or bovine serum albumin; prompt on blood, blood plasma, or bovine albumin]
blenders [accept Waring blenders; prompt on agitators, mixers, or liquidisers; do not accept or prompt on “food processors”]
parts: Name this substance whose fetal bovine form is a common cell culture medium. The albumin found in this substance is a common blocker in lab techniques like ELISA (ee-LIE-suh).

Like centrifuges, these common devices can mechanically lyse (LICE) platelets to create a serum-free medium. One of these devices separated conjugating pairs of cells in a study of Hfr strains by Wollman and Jacob, and one made by Waring separated phages from cells in the Hershey-Chase experiment.
Platelet lysate is a common serum-free medium for the mesenchymal (meh-ZAN-ky-mull) type of these cells, which are pluripotent if they can mature into any type of cell.
Name this king, who defeated a coalition of Scots and Vikings at the Battle of Brunanburh. In 927 he became the first King of all of England.
The first region to accept Athelstan as king was this kingdom, where his father Edward had died in 924. A ruler of this kingdom erected a 150-mile earthwork to defend it from neighbouring Wales.

Athelstan finally became king of all England after conquering a kingdom named for this northern city. Richard III was the last king of a house named for this city, which fought the Lancasters in the Wars of the Roses.

answers: extrusion [or extruding; or extrusion molding; accept the extrude tool; prompt on molding with "what form of molding?"; prompt on pushing]
3D printers [or 3 dimensional printers; prompt on printers]

CAD software [or computer-aided design software; accept CAM software or computer-aided manufacturing software; accept CAGD software or computer-aided geometric design software; prompt on 3D modeling or 3D design software]
parts: Name this manufacturing technique often contrasted with casting and drawing, which can involve using a hydraulic press to push an aluminum billet through a steel die.
The filaments produced by Bowden extruders can be used in fused filament fabrication, a process used by these additive manufacturing devices that manufacture solid objects with depth.

This type of software usually has an extrude tool that takes a 2D shape and extends it along the perpendicular dimension. SolidWorks and Autodesk are examples of this type of software, which output files instructing 3D printers how to print objects modeled in them.

answers: A Universal History of Infamy [or A Universal History of Iniquity or Historia universal de la infamia]
Jorge Luis Borges [or Jorge Francisco Isidoro Luis Borges Acevedo]
detectives [accept The Savage Detectives or Los Detectives Salvajes] (by Roberto Bolaño)
parts: Name this collection which includes the short stories "The Uncivil Teacher of Court Etiquette Kôtsuké no Suké" and "The Widow Ching – Pirate."
Flores attributed the growth in magical realism to this author's Franz Kafka translations. This author of A Universal History of Infamy wrote "The Library of Babel."

Flores argued the "well-knit plots" of magical realist novels originate from reading novels in a genre titled for this profession. The visceral realists Belano and Lima track a poet to the Sonora desert in a novel titled for this job.

answers: Guantanamo Bay [or Centro de detención de Guantánamo; accept GTMO; accept Gitmo]
parts: Name this intelligence officer who was succeeded by William Burns as CIA director in February 2021. She was criticized for running a black site in Thailand under conditions described in John Yoo's torture memos.

Both Haspel and Burns are investigating odd instances of neurological problems among foreign service operatives which was first documented in agents returning from this city. Stubbs et al. argued that a rare jungle cricket was causing a "syndrome" named for this city.
Joe Biden has declared interest to Burns in closing this American detention facility in Cuba.

answers: cerium [or Ce; accept cerium ammonium nitrate; prompt on ceria or CAN]
rare-earth elements [accept rare-earths or rare-earth metals; prompt on Group 3]
parts: Name this element which is miscible with thorium, which it replaced in gas mantles. This element's ammonium nitrate is a useful single-electron oxidizing agent.
The placement of thorium underneath cerium in the periodic table was first suggested by this scientist's actinide concept, which was prompted by their codiscovery of several transuranium elements.

With a prevalence on par with copper, cerium is the most common member of these elements. This group of elements is a superset of the lanthanides that includes yttrium and scandium, which are largely indistinguishable.
Homer used potnia theron to refer to this Greek goddess of the hunt in Book 21 of the Iliad.
Older statues of Artemis depict her holding a stag and one of these animals. The hands of the Seated Goddess of Çatalhöyük (kuh-tal-hoo-yuk) rest atop two of these animals.

Two panthers flank one of these creatures resembling a potnia theron-like figure in the western pediment of the Temple of Artemis at Corfu. Mopsus, the Argonaut, was killed by animals formed from the blood of one of these creatures.

answers: [10] Shaw introduced a standard of negligence in tort cases in a case named for a defendant of this surname. A person of the same surname provided the funds to start Gallaudet (gal-uh-DET) University and served as Postmaster General. ANSWER: Kendall [or Amos Kendall; or George K. Kendall]
Webster [or Daniel Webster; or Commonwealth v. Webster; or the Webster-Parkman Case]
parts: Shaw introduced a standard of negligence in tort cases in a case named for a defendant of this surname. A person of the same surname provided the funds to start Gallaudet (gal-uh-DET) University and served as Postmaster General.

Shaw wrote a defining majority opinion in Commonwealth v. Hunt which ruled that these entities were not engaging in criminal conspiracy. The opinion allowed the formation of later examples of these entities such as the Knights of Labor.

Shaw was best known for a murder case involving a Dr. Parkman and a man with this surname. Another man of this surname gave a speech asserting that "there are those who love it" while arguing in a case involving John Wheelock.
Name this composer whose Symphony No. 1 incorporates blues progressions and elements of popular African-American music and is subtitled Afro-American.

The third movement of Still's "Afro-American" Symphony opens with a melody very similar to this composer's show tune "I Got Rhythm." This composer fused jazz and classical music in his piece Rhapsody in Blue.
The "Afro-American" Symphony begins with a bluesy solo for this instrument. This wind instrument's family includes the hecklephone and a "d'amore" variety.
Name this character, who befriends the poet Homeless while in Stravinsky's clinic. His only personal belonging is a "greasy black cap" with an embroidered "M."

Like the Master, this author was derided by critics after Joseph Stalin watched their play The White Guard 15 times. The Master is an autobiographical depiction of this author of The Master and Margarita.

Bulgakov satirized Soviet literary critics with this literary organization in the novel. Behemoth burns down this organization's headquarters above Griboedov's restaurant, and the chairman of this organization, Mikhail Berlioz, is decapitated by a street car.
Identify these functions which are written as a constant times labor to the alpha times capital to the beta in Cobb-Douglas form.

To guarantee the existence of a unique steady-state, production functions are assumed to satisfy the Inada conditions in neoclassical models of this phenomenon which is quantified by an increase in real GDP.
This simple endogenous growth model does not assume diminishing returns to capital, so its namesake Cobb-Douglas function is linear in capital.

Name this concept identified by the Arabic word nafs, which Sufis (soo-fees) believe undergo three stages of development as one becomes a better Muslim. Like Christianity, this concept is also thought to be immortal.

Muslims seek to improve their relationship with Allah, which leads to the improvement of this set of morals. In contrast with adab (ah-dahb), this Arabic term refers to one's internal values or disposition.
The term fajr describes a tranquil stage of the soul that Allah will call to Heaven, as described in Surah al-Fajr. The Fajr prayer, one of the 5 daily prayers, is performed at this time of day.

answers: nitrogen vacancy centers [or nitrogen vacancies or NV centers or color centers; prompt on vacancies or point defects]
fluorescence [or word forms like being fluorescent; prompt on photoluminescence or descriptions of giving off light]
parts: Name these specific crystal defects, which may be able to serve as qubits at room temperature because they can act as single photon sources with long coherence times.
NV centers are defects where a nitrogen and an empty space are found in the lattice of this substance, whose normally periodic lattice makes it a 10 on the Mohs scale.

Nanodiamonds with NV centers can display this phenomenon with a notably higher quantum yield than quantum dots. Due to this property, nanodiamonds may replace coumarine and rhodamine in some biological applications.

answers: works of art [or artworks; accept any reasonable answer that mentions art]
parts: Name these objects, whose beauty and appreciation is studied in aesthetics.
This philosopher argued in one essay that art is able to create strife between the "Earth" and the "World." That essay argues that art begins with an Ursprung, or a "primal leap."

Heidegger's analysis of van Gogh's A Pair of Shoes in "The Origin of the Work of Art" was discussed using this method in Jacques Derrida's book Restitutions. Derrida developed this post-structuralist approach which aims to subvert binary oppositions.

answers: ventriloquism [accept word forms; accept biloquism; accept descriptions of imitating voices or throwing voices; prompt on pretending to be someone else or making someone hear voices or similar descriptions with "What method is used to do that?"]
Jewish-American [accept specific forms of Judaism, such as Hasidism]
parts: Name this activity which Carwin performs to drive Theodore mad in Charles Brockden Brown's novel Wieland. A description is acceptable.
Banerjee criticized this author's description of a Native American "affected by sort of a cold shadow of the white man's curiosity" while seeing Hester Prynne wearing the Scarlet Letter.

Jennifer Glaser discussed racial ventriloquism in America in reference to this ethnic group. A novel by a member of this ethnic group discusses how the African-American professor Coleman Silk attempts to pass as a member of this group.

answers: Spartan women [accept obvious equivalents; prompt on partial answer]
parts: Identify these people who, unusually for their time, were allowed to own land. They wore knee-length chitons rather than ankle-length ones during races.

Female participation in athletics was mandated by this Spartan ruler so that they would be strong for childbirth. This lawgiver created the Great Rhetra constitution and implemented the agoge (AH-go-gay) system.
Because many of the domestic tasks typical for women in the rest of Greece were not done by Spartan women, they were instead performed by this class of Spartan serfs.

answers: existence [or there exists; or existential quantifier]
parts: Name this property, which in predicate logic names a quantifier that looks like a backwards capital E. Kant argued that the ontological argument was invalid because this property is not a predicate.

Routley's modal Meinongianism has been championed by Graham Priest, who is best-known arguing that these things can be true, a view called dialetheism. Anything follows validly from one according to the "principle of explosion."

This philosopher criticized Meinong for including non-existent objects in his ontology in "On Denoting," which introduced his theory of definite descriptions. He wrote Principia Mathematica with Alfred Whitehead.
